ColloExa.EXAMPLE: He had worked all his life in the mine.
The boys played video games all day.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: Hannah didn't say a single word
EXAMPLE.GLOSS: during the whole of the journey

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Almost all of the music was from Italian operas.

Sense.EXAMPLE: I've heard it all before.
She'd given up all hope of having a child.

Sense.DEF: every one of a number of people or things, or every thing or person of a particular type
Sense.EXAMPLE: Someone's taken all my books!
Will all the girls please stand over here.
All children should be taught to swim.
16 per cent of all new cars sold in Western Europe these days are diesel-engined.
They all speak excellent English.

GramExa.EXAMPLE: important changes that will affect all of us

Sense.DEF: the only thing or things
Sense.EXAMPLE: All you need is a hammer and some nails.
All I'm asking for is a little respect.

Sense.DEF: everything
Sense.EXAMPLE: I'm doing all I can to help her.
I hope all is well with you.
All was dark and silent down by the harbour wall.

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that you mean the greatest possible amount of the quality you are mentioning
Sense.EXAMPLE: Can any of us say in all honesty that we did everything we could?

Sense.DEF: used in negative statements and questions to emphasize what you are saying
Sense.EXAMPLE: They've done nothing at all to try and put the problem right.
He's not looking at all well.
'Do you mind if I stay a little longer?' 'No, not at all.'
Has the situation improved at all?

Sense.DEF: many different kinds of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Social workers have to deal with all kinds of problems.

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that your statement is true of one particular person, thing, or place more than any other
Sense.EXAMPLE: Of course, you shouldn't have done it. You of all people should know that.
She did not want to quarrel with Maria today, of all days.

Sense.DEF: used to show that you are considering every part of a situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: All in all, it had been one of the most miserable days of Henry's life.

Sense.DEF: in spite of a particular fact
Sense.EXAMPLE: For all his faults, he's a kind-hearted old soul.
For all my love of landscape, nothing could persuade me to spend another day in the Highlands.

Sense.DEF: including every thing or person
Sense.EXAMPLE: In all, there were 215 candidates.
We received £1550 in cash and promises of another £650, making £2200 in all.

Subsense.DEF: including the thing or things just mentioned
Subsense.EXAMPLE: They ate the whole fish - head, bones, tail, and all.

Subsense.DEF: used to emphasize a remark that you have just added
Subsense.EXAMPLE: And you can take that smelly old coat out of here, and all!

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize how large or small an amount actually is
Sense.EXAMPLE: The game lasted all of 58 seconds.
The repairs are going to cost all of £15,000.

Sense.DEF: used to say that unless something is done completely, it is not acceptable
Sense.EXAMPLE: Half-heartedness won't do - it's got to be all or nothing.

Sense.DEF: to make the greatest possible effort in order to achieve something
Sense.EXAMPLE: The coach expects every player to give their all in every game.

Sense.LEXUNIT: it was all I could do to do sth
Sense.DEF: used to say that you only just succeeded in doing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was all I could do to stop them hitting each other.

Sense.DEF: used to remind someone about an important point that needs to be considered
Sense.EXAMPLE: When all's said and done, he's only a kid.

Sense.DEF: completely
Sense.EXAMPLE: You shouldn't be sitting here by yourself, all alone.
a strange woman, dressed all in black

EXAMPLE.TEXT: If people want more freedom of choice, then I'm
'It was a dreadful experience.' 'Never mind, it's

Subsense.DEF: everywhere on an object or surface
Subsense.EXAMPLE: There were bits of paper all over the floor.
He has cuts all over his legs.

Subsense.DEF: everywhere in a place
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Antique clocks from all over the world are on display.
People came from all over the country.
They're putting up new offices all over the place.

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize how much better, easier etc something is than it would be in a different situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: Clayton's achievement is all the more remarkable when you consider his poor performance last season.
The job was made all the easier by having the proper tools.

Sense.DEF: almost completely
Sense.EXAMPLE: Britain's coal industry has all but disappeared.
His left arm was all but useless.

Sense.DEF: used to mean 'very' when talking about a bad situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: All too often it's the mother who gets blamed for her children's behaviour.
In these conditions it was all too easy to make mistakes.

Sense.DEF: all the time from the beginning while something was happening
Sense.EXAMPLE: Chapman had known all along that the plan wouldn't work.
We had to admit that Dad had been right all along.

Sense.DEF: used when giving the score of a game in which both players or teams have scored the same number of points
Sense.EXAMPLE: The game ended one-all.

Sense.DEF: including everything or everyone
Sense.EXAMPLE: a project costing £10,000, all told

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone's success or happiness has ended
Sense.EXAMPLE: If someone tells the police, then it'll be all up with me.

Sense.DEF: someone who is not all there seems stupid or slightly crazy
to be showing a lot of a particular quality or type of behaviour
Sense.EXAMPLE: The mayor and mayoress were all smiles and kisses during the grand ceremony.

Sense.DEF: to be trying to kiss someone and touch them, especially in a sexual way
Sense.EXAMPLE: Before I could speak, he was all over me.

Sense.DEF: very
Sense.EXAMPLE: You're getting me all confused.

Sense.DEF: used to say that a particular way of behaving is typical of someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was late of course, but that's Tim all over!

Sense.DEF: to be very tired
used to report what someone said or did, when telling a story
Sense.EXAMPLE: He drove me home, and he was all, 'I love this car ... it's like a rocket.'

Sense.DEF: not very
Sense.EXAMPLE: It doesn't sound all that good, does it?
I don't think it matters all that much.

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone or something is not very attractive or desirable
Sense.EXAMPLE: I don't know why you keep chasing her around. She's not all that.

Sense.DEF: consisting of or made of only one kind of thing
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-male club
an all-wool coat

Sense.DEF: continuing for the whole day or night
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-day seminar
an all-night café

Sense.DEF: the Muslim name for God
having qualities that are considered to be typically American and that American people admire, such as being healthy and working hard
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-American family

Sense.DEF: belonging to a group of players who have been chosen as the best in their sport at American universities
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-American football player

Sense.DEF: good at doing many different things, especially sports
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-around athlete

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel less afraid, worried etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: The president made a statement to allay public anxiety.

Subsense.DEF: official permission to begin doing something

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: We've got the all clear for the new project.

Subsense.DEF: a signal such as a loud whistle that tells you that a dangerous situation has ended

Sense.DEF: everyone who wants to take part in something, especially a competition
Sense.EXAMPLE: The marathon is open to all comers.

Sense.DEF: a statement that someone has done something wrong or illegal, but that has not been proved

GramExa.EXAMPLE: an allegation that senior government figures were involved

Sense.DEF: to say that something is true or that someone has done something wrong, although it has not been proved

GramExa.EXAMPLE: It was alleged that the policeman had accepted bribes.
The prosecution alleged that the man had been responsible for an act of terrorism.
The water is alleged to be polluted with mercury.

Sense.DEF: an alleged crime, fact etc is one that someone says has happened or is true, although it has not been proved
Sense.EXAMPLE: their alleged involvement in international terrorism

EXAMPLE.TEXT: made the complaint at a police station in York.

Sense.DEF: used when reporting something that people say is true, although it has not been proved
Sense.EXAMPLE: a sports car, allegedly stolen in Manchester

Sense.DEF: loyalty to a leader, country, belief etc

EXAMPLE.GLOSS: have a duty to give allegiance

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.

Sense.EXAMPLE: an oath of allegiance

ColloExa.GLOSS: start to support a different person, group etc

Sense.DEF: a story, painting etc in which the events and characters represent ideas or teach a moral lesson
a piece of music played or sung quickly

DEF.TEXT: another spelling of

Sense.DEF: including everyone or everything
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-embracing vision of society

Sense.DEF: a tool used to turn an Allen screw
a type of screw with a hole that has six sides
a tool used to turn an Allen screw
a substance that causes an allergy
having an allergy

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I'm allergic to penicillin.

Sense.DEF: caused by an allergy
if you are allergic to something, you do not like it and try to avoid it - used humorously
Sense.EXAMPLE: Most men are allergic to housework!

Sense.DEF: a medical condition in which you become ill or in which your skin becomes red and painful because you have eaten or touched a particular substance
to make something less painful or difficult to deal with

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: a new medicine to alleviate the symptoms of flu

Sense.EXAMPLE: measures to alleviate poverty

Sense.DEF: a narrow street between or behind buildings, not usually used by cars
Sense.EXAMPLE: The alley led to the railway bridge.
She found the side alley where the stage door was located.

Sense.DEF: very suitable for someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The job sounds right up your alley.

Sense.DEF: a cat that lives on the streets and does not belong to anyone

DEF.TEXT: an

Sense.DEF: completely - used when describing a quality that you think is extreme
Sense.EXAMPLE: If he weren't so all-fired sure of himself, I'd like him better.

Sense.DEF: used to say that a situation is very busy and full of activity
Sense.EXAMPLE: It was all go from 8.00 until we finished at 5.00.

Sense.DEF: an arrangement in which two or more countries, groups etc agree to work together to try to change or achieve something

ColloExa.GLOSS: agree to work together
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: The companies have formed an alliance to market the product.

Sense.DEF: a group of two or more countries, groups etc who work together to achieve something
Sense.EXAMPLE: independent organizations and alliances

Sense.DEF: if two groups, countries etc are in alliance, they work together to achieve something or protect each another
Sense.EXAMPLE: Relief workers in alliance with local charities are trying to help the famine victims.

Sense.DEF: a close relationship, especially a marriage, between people
belonging or relating to the countries that fought with Britain, the US etc in the First or Second World War
Sense.EXAMPLE: an Allied bombing raid
Allied forces

Sense.DEF: to be related to something or to be very similar
Sense.EXAMPLE: Anthropology is closely allied to the field of psychology.

Sense.DEF: connected with each other because of being similar to or dependent on each other
Sense.EXAMPLE: agriculture and allied industries

Sense.DEF: joined by the same political, military, or economic aims
Sense.EXAMPLE: loosely allied guerilla groups

Sense.DEF: the countries that fought together against Germany during the First and Second World War
a large animal with a long mouth and tail and sharp teeth that lives in the hot wet parts of the US and China
the skin of this animal used as leather
Sense.EXAMPLE: alligator shoes

Sense.DEF: extremely important
Sense.EXAMPLE: the all-important question in everyone's minds

Sense.DEF: used to describe the total cost of something, or the total amount of money charged for something

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: all-in deals to Australia and New Zealand

Sense.EXAMPLE: The hourly rate is £20 all in.

Sense.DEF: extremely tired
Sense.EXAMPLE: You look all-in. Are you OK?

Sense.DEF: including the cost of everything in the price charged

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: an all-inclusive vacation cruise

Sense.DEF: combining two or more things that are usually separate into one thing
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-in-one TV and video

Sense.DEF: the use of several words together that begin with the same sound or letter in order to make a special effect, especially in poetry
an occasion when you spend the whole night studying or doing written work in university
to use something for a particular purpose, give something to a particular person etc, especially after an official decision has been made

GramExa.EXAMPLE: You should allocate the same amount of time to each question.
One million dollars was allocated for disaster relief.
Several patients were waiting to be allocated a bed.

Sense.DEF: the amount or share of something that has been allocated for a particular purpose
Sense.EXAMPLE: Twelve hours a week seemed a generous allocation of your time.

Sense.DEF: the decision to allocate something, or the act of allocating it

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the allocation of funds to universities

Sense.DEF: to use a particular amount of time for something, or give a particular share of money, space etc to someone or something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Try and allot 2 or 3 hours a day to revision.
Each school will be allotted twenty seats.

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: Everyone who works for the company has been allotted 10 shares.

RunOn.EXAMPLE: The department has already spent more than its allotted budget.

Sense.DEF: an amount or share of something such as money or time that is given to someone or something, or the process of doing this
Sense.EXAMPLE: The budget allotment for each county is below what is needed.

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the allotment of shares in the company

Sense.DEF: a small area of land that people can rent for growing vegetables

Sense.ACTIV: TRY TO DO OR GET STH
Sense.DEF: done in a very determined way, and involving a lot of energy or anger
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-out effort to win

EXAMPLE.TEXT: on the ice if they want to win.

Head.COMMENT: usage note not working. Needed here for allow/permit/let

Sense.DEF: to let someone do or have something, or let something happen

GramExa.EXAMPLE: My parents wouldn't allow me to go to the party.
Women are not allowed to enter the mosque.
Don't allow your problems to dominate your life.
Passengers are allowed one item of hand luggage each.
How much time are we allowed?
I don't allow the cat in the bedroom.
The audience is not allowed backstage.

ColloExa.GLOSS: something is or is not officially permitted
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: Are dictionaries allowed in the exam?

Sense.EXAMPLE: We don't allow diving in the pool.

Sense.DEF: to make it possible for something to happen or for someone to do something, especially something helpful or useful
Sense.EXAMPLE: This adjustment of the figures allows a fairer comparison.

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Our new system will allow for more efficient use of resources.
A 24-hour ceasefire allowed the two armies to reach an agreement.
a seatbelt that allows the driver greater freedom of movement

Sense.DEF: to be sure that you have enough time, money, food etc available for a particular purpose

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Allow yourselves plenty of time to get to the airport.
I've allowed half a bottle of wine for each person.

Sense.DEF: to accept that something is correct or true, or that something is acceptable according to the rules or law

GramExa.EXAMPLE: I allow that there may have been a mistake.

Sense.EXAMPLE: The judge allowed the evidence.

Sense.DEF: used as a polite way of offering to help someone do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: 'Allow me,' the waiter said, opening the door.

Sense.DEF: to consider the possible facts, problems, costs etc involved in something when making a plan, calculation, or judgment
Sense.EXAMPLE: Allowing for inflation, the cost of the project will be $2 million.
You should always allow for the possibility that it might rain.

Sense.DEF: to make it possible for something to happen or be accepted
Sense.EXAMPLE: The facts allow of only one interpretation.

Sense.DEF: acceptable according to the rules
Sense.EXAMPLE: The maximum allowable dosage is two tablets a day.

Sense.DEF: allowable costs are costs that you do not pay tax on
Sense.EXAMPLE: allowable deductions such as alimony and business expenses

Sense.DEF: an amount of money that you are given regularly or for a special purpose

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: His father gives him a monthly allowance of £200.

Sense.EXAMPLE: Sales staff get a generous mileage allowance or a company car.
If you are entitled to sickness allowance, you must claim it from your employer.

Sense.DEF: an amount of something that is acceptable or safe
Sense.EXAMPLE: Passengers' baggage allowance is 75 pounds per person.

Sense.DEF: an amount of money that you can earn without paying tax on it
a small amount of money that a parent regularly gives to a child
something that you consider when deciding what is likely to happen, what you should expect etc

GramExa.EXAMPLE: There is always an allowance in insurance premiums for whether someone smokes or not.

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: The budget makes allowances for extra staff when needed.

Sense.DEF: to let someone behave in a way you do not normally approve of, because you know there are special reasons for their behaviour
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dad's under pressure - you have to make allowances.

Sense.DEF: a metal that consists of two or more metals mixed together
Sense.EXAMPLE: Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc.

Sense.DEF: to mix one metal with another
having complete power or control
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-powerful dictator

Sense.DEF: able to be used in any situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-purpose cleaner

Sense.DEF: satisfactory, but not excellent
Sense.EXAMPLE: 'What's the food like?' 'It's all right, but the place on campus is better.'
'How's school going, Steve?' 'Oh, all right, I guess.'

Sense.DEF: not ill, hurt, or upset or not having any problems
Sense.EXAMPLE: Kate looks really unhappy - I'd better make sure she's all right.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: Tony was worried about the meeting but it

Sense.DEF: to be successful in your job, life etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: She's doing all right - she's got a job with Microsoft.

Sense.DEF: used to say whether something is suitable or convenient

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Is Thursday morning all right with you?

EXAMPLE.TEXT: We'll eat at eight. Does that

Sense.DEF: used to make someone feel less afraid or worried
Sense.EXAMPLE: It's all right, Mommy's here.

Sense.DEF: used to reply to someone who thanks you or says they are sorry about something
used to ask or give permission for something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Would it be all right if I left early today?

GramExa.PROPFORM: be all right to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Is it all right to bring my dog?

Sense.DEF: used to agree with someone's suggestion, although you may be slightly unwilling
Sense.EXAMPLE: 'Why not come along?' 'Oh, all right.'

Sense.DEF: used to check that someone understands what you have said, or to show that you understand
Sense.EXAMPLE: I'll leave a key with the neighbours, all right?
'The train leaves at 5.30.' 'All right, I'm coming!'

Sense.DEF: used when asking in a threatening or angry way what someone's intentions are
Sense.EXAMPLE: All right, you two. What are you doing in my room?

Sense.DEF: used to introduce a new subject or to end a conversation
Sense.EXAMPLE: All right, now I'd like to introduce our first speaker.

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone else does not have the problems that you have, or that you are jealous because someone else is luckier than you

EXAMPLE.TEXT: 'I get eight weeks' holiday a year.' 'Well,

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that you are certain about something
Sense.EXAMPLE: 'Are you sure it was Bill?' 'Oh, yes, it was him all right.'

Sense.DEF: used to say you are happy about something you have just been told
Sense.EXAMPLE: You passed? All right!

Sense.DEF: used to describe someone you like or approve of
Sense.EXAMPLE: 'The new boss isn't too bad, is she?' 'No, she's all right.'

Sense.DEF: used as a greeting when you meet someone you know well, or reply to a greeting
Sense.EXAMPLE: 'How are you, John?' 'Oh, all right - can't complain.'

Sense.DEF: used to describe someone's attitude when they do not care about other people as long as they themselves are happy, comfortable etc

Sense.LEXUNIT: it'll be all right on the night
Sense.DEF: used to say that something will be successful, even though there have been lots of problems
Sense.EXAMPLE: Workmen have yet to finish the new complex, but the organisers are confident it will be all right on the night.

Sense.DEF: used to say that you are describing the total quality or effect of something, rather than the details
Sense.EXAMPLE: All round it's not a bad car.
It was a nasty business all round.

Sense.DEF: good at doing many different things
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-round athlete

Sense.DEF: someone with many different skills
Sense.EXAMPLE: a good all-rounder

DEF.TEXT: an all-seater football ground,
etc is one where everyone has a seat

Sense.DEF: an all-singing, all-dancing machine or system can do many things because it is so technically advanced - used humorously
the dried fruit of a tropical American tree, crushed and used in cooking
including many famous actors, sports players etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-star cast

Sense.DEF: all-terrain vehicles are very strong with thick tyres and are suitable for use in many different conditions
Sense.EXAMPLE: an all-terrain bike

Sense.DEF: used when you compare things to say that one of them is the best, worst etc that there has ever been

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: The price of wheat had reached an all-time low.

Sense.DEF: to mention something or someone indirectly
Sense.EXAMPLE: Rick didn't want to discuss his past, though he alluded darkly to 'some bad things that happened.'

Sense.DEF: a mysterious, exciting, or desirable quality

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the allure of foreign travel

Sense.EXAMPLE: At 50, she had lost none of her sexual allure.

RunOn.EXAMPLE: harmonies that never fail to allure the listener
the alluring magic of Hong Kong

Sense.DEF: something said or written that mentions a subject, person etc indirectly

EXAMPLE.TEXT: to the former President in its report.

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: Eliot's poetry is full of biblical allusions.
In his poetry we find many allusions to the human body.

Sense.DEF: made of soil left by rivers, lakes, floods etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: alluvial flood plains

Sense.DEF: soil left by rivers, lakes, floods etc
a country that agrees to help or support another country in a war
Sense.EXAMPLE: a meeting of the European allies

Sense.DEF: the group of countries including Britain and the US that fought together in the First and Second World Wars
someone who helps and supports you when other people are trying to oppose you

EXAMPLE.TEXT: Ridley was one of the Queen's

Sense.EXAMPLE: She knew she had found an ally in Ted.

Sense.DEF: something that helps you succeed in a difficult situation
Sense.EXAMPLE: Exercise is an important ally in your campaign to lose weight.

Sense.DEF: to help and support other people or countries, especially in a war or disagreement

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Some of the northern cities allied themselves with the emperor.

Sense.DEF: the school, college etc that someone used to attend
the song of a particular school, college etc
a book produced each year containing information about a particular subject, especially a sport, or important dates, times etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: a football almanac
a nautical almanac

Sense.DEF: expressions used to talk about God that emphasize His power
an expression used when you are angry or upset. Some people consider this use offensive.
a very loud noise, argument etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: There was an almighty bang and the car came to a halt.

Sense.DEF: a flat pale nut with brown skin that tastes sweet, or the tree that produces these nuts
Sense.EXAMPLE: Stir in the ground almonds and egg.

Sense.DEF: nearly, but not completely or not quite
Sense.EXAMPLE: Have you almost finished?
Supper's almost ready.
It was almost midnight.
Almost nothing was done to improve the situation.

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: Marsha visits her son almost every day.

Sense.DEF: money, food etc given to poor people in the past
in Britain in the past, a house where a poor person was allowed to live without paying rent

DEF.TEXT: a tropical plant with thick leaves that are filled with a liquid which is used to make medicine,
etc

Sense.DEF: high up in the air

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: He emerged, triumphantly holding a baby aloft.

Sense.DEF: if you are alone in a place, there is no one with you

EXAMPLE.TEXT: My wife and I like to spend time

Sense.DEF: without any friends or people you know

EXAMPLE.GLOSS: she had no family or friends to help her or look after her

Sense.DEF: feeling unhappy and lonely

EXAMPLE.TEXT: I cried like a child because I

Sense.DEF: without any help from other people
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was left to raise their two children alone.

Sense.DEF: without including anything else
Sense.EXAMPLE: The case will cost thousands of pounds in legal fees alone.

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that there is only one person who knows, can do something etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Julie alone knew the truth.

Sense.DEF: to start working or living on your own, especially after working or living with other people
Sense.EXAMPLE: After years of working for a big company I decided to go it alone.

Sense.DEF: to stop annoying or interrupting someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: 'Leave me alone!' she screamed.

Sense.DEF: to stop touching an object or changing something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Leave those cakes alone. They're for the guests.

ColloExa.GLOSS: not change something that is satisfactory
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: In economic matters, they should leave well alone.

Sense.DEF: used to emphasize that something belongs to someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The responsibility is yours and yours alone.

Sense.DEF: to not be the only person to do something
Sense.EXAMPLE: You're not alone in feeling upset, believe me.

Subsense.DEF: to be strong and independent
Subsense.EXAMPLE: the courage to stand alone

Subsense.DEF: to be at a distance from other objects or buildings
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The house stood alone at the end of the road.

Sense.DEF: going forward
Sense.EXAMPLE: I was driving along, thinking about Chris.
a group of children walking along in a line

Sense.DEF: to go or come to a place where something is happening
Sense.EXAMPLE: You're welcome to come along if you like.
I think I'll go along and watch the game.

Sense.DEF: to take someone or something with you to a place
Sense.EXAMPLE: Mandy brought some of her friends along.
Why don't you take your guitar along?

Sense.DEF: to arrive
Sense.EXAMPLE: Another bus should be along in a minute.
Every so often, a band comes along that changes music history.

Sense.DEF: to improve, develop, or make progress
Sense.EXAMPLE: After a five-hour operation, Wendy is coming along just fine.

Sense.DEF: together with someone or something else
Sense.EXAMPLE: Dunne was murdered, along with three guards.

Sense.DEF: all the time from the beginning, while something was happening
Sense.EXAMPLE: They should have known all along that she was lying.

Sense.DEF: from one place on something such as a line, road, or edge towards the other end of it
Sense.EXAMPLE: We were driving along Follyfoot Road.
She glanced anxiously along the line of faces.
He slid his hand along her arm.

Sense.DEF: forming a line beside something long
Sense.EXAMPLE: The palm trees along the shore swayed in the wind.
the toolbar along the top of your screen

Sense.DEF: a particular distance away, on or beside something long such as a line, road, edge etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Hugo's house was about two hundred yards away along the main street.

Sense.DEF: during a process or experience, or during someone's life
Sense.EXAMPLE: I've been lucky, but I've had my share of heartbreak along the way.

Sense.DEF: next to the side of something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Children's prices are shown alongside adult prices.

Sense.DEF: used to say that people or things do something or exist together at the same time
Sense.EXAMPLE: Charles spent a week working alongside the miners.
Organized crime continued to flourish alongside the mainstream economy.

Sense.DEF: in comparison with something
Sense.EXAMPLE: His achievement may seem small alongside the great triumphs of 20th century technology.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: soccer and cricket as a major sport.

Sense.DEF: unfriendly and deliberately not talking to other people

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: They worked hard, but tended to stay aloof from the local inhabitants.
She had always kept herself aloof from the boys in class.

Sense.EXAMPLE: Beneath that aloof exterior, Gayle is a warm, sympathetic person.

Sense.DEF: deliberately not becoming involved in something

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: Initially, the President remained aloof from the campaign.
The doctor held himself somewhat aloof from the rest of the ship's crew.

Sense.DEF: if you read, laugh, say something etc aloud, you read etc so that people can hear you

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: Joanne, would you read the poem aloud?
The pain made him cry aloud.
She could have laughed aloud.

ColloExa.GLOSS: say the things you are thinking
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: 'What did you say?' ' Sorry, I was just thinking aloud.'

Sense.DEF: surrounding or on all sides of something or someone
Sense.EXAMPLE: The whole family was sitting around the dinner table.
The Romans built a defensive wall around the city.
She wore a beautiful silk shawl around her shoulders.
People crowded around to see what was happening.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: We would hear the birds singing

Sense.DEF: moving in a circle
Sense.EXAMPLE: A helicopter was circling around, looking for somewhere to land.
They danced around the bonfire.

Sense.DEF: in or to many places or parts of an area
Sense.EXAMPLE: He wandered around the streets, looking in shop windows.
There are over 40 radio stations dotted around the country.
When I finished college, I travelled around for a while before I got my first job.
Since it's your first day here, would you like me to show you around?
We started looking around for somewhere to live.

Subsense.DEF: in an area near a place or person
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Is there a bank around here?
When you've been around a person long enough, you start to know how they'll react.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: Catherine was the most beautiful girl

Subsense.DEF: if someone or something is around, they are somewhere in the place where you are
Subsense.EXAMPLE: Why is there never a policeman around when you need one?
Jake went down to the bar, but there was no-one around that he knew.
Is your dad around?

Sense.DEF: on the other side of something, or to the other side of it without going through it or over it
Sense.EXAMPLE: If the gate's locked, you'll have to go around the side of the house.
There's a door around the back.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: and straight into the arms of John Delaney.

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone or something turns so that they face in the opposite direction
Sense.EXAMPLE: Rex spun around and kicked the gun from her hand.
Slowly he turned the boat around towards the open sea.

Sense.DEF: used when guessing a number, amount, time etc, without being exact
Sense.EXAMPLE: There must have been around 40,000 people in the stadium.
The whole project will probably cost around $3 million.
Most guests started to make their way home around about ten o'clock.

Sense.DEF: existing
Sense.EXAMPLE: That joke's been around for years.
Manson has a reputation as one of the most stylish designers around.

Sense.DEF: if something is organized around a particular person or thing, it is organized according to their needs, wishes, ideas etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Why does everything have to be arranged around what Callum wants to do?
Their whole society was built around their religious beliefs.

Sense.DEF: used to show that someone spends time in a place without doing anything useful
Sense.EXAMPLE: I've been waiting around all morning.
They could be seen hanging around street corners, watching the girls go by.

Sense.DEF: a way around a difficult situation or problem is a way to solve it or avoid it
Sense.EXAMPLE: We must find a way around these difficulties.
The company is expected to get around this problem by borrowing from the banks.

Sense.DEF: to other people or positions
Sense.EXAMPLE: Write your name on this list and pass it around.
Someone's been moving the furniture around.

Subsense.DEF: to have had experience of many different situations so that you can deal with new situations confidently
Subsense.EXAMPLE: You could tell this guy had been around a bit by the knowing way he talked.

Subsense.DEF: to have had many sexual experiences - used humorously

Sense.DEF: used to show the length of a line surrounding something
Sense.EXAMPLE: Redwood trees can measure 30 or 40 feet around.

Sense.DEF: excitement, especially sexual excitement
to make you become interested, expect something etc
Sense.EXAMPLE: Matt's behavior was arousing the interest of the neighbors.

DEF.TEXT: to make someone feel very unfriendly and angry, or

Sense.EXAMPLE: A great deal of anger was aroused by Campbell's decision.

Sense.DEF: to make someone feel sexually excited
Sense.EXAMPLE: She felt aroused by the pressure of his body so close to hers.

Sense.DEF: to wake someone

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Anne had to be aroused from a deep sleep.

DEF.TEXT: the notes of a musical
played separately but quickly one after the other

Sense.EXAMPLE: music by Mozart, arr. Britten

Sense.DEF: to make someone come to court to hear what their crime is

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Thompson was arraigned on a charge of murder.

Sense.DEF: to organize or make plans for something such as a meeting, party, or trip
Sense.EXAMPLE: Contact your local branch to arrange an appointment.
I'd like to arrange a business loan.

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Have you arranged to meet Mark this weekend?
Beth arranged a meeting with the marketing director.
We still have to arrange how to get home.

Sense.DEF: to make it possible for someone to have or do something

GramExa.EXAMPLE: The company will arrange for a taxi to meet you at the airport.

GramExa.PROPFORM: arrange for sb to do sth
GramExa.EXAMPLE: Dave arranged for someone to drive him home.

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: The children were arranged in lines according to height.

Sense.DEF: to write or change a piece of music so that it is suitable for a particular instrument

GramExa.EXAMPLE: a symphony arranged for the piano

plans and preparations that you must make so that something can happen

Sense.DEF: something that has been organized or agreed on

GramExa.EXAMPLE: An arrangement between the two couples ensured there was always someone to look after the children.
The school has an arrangement with local businesses.

ColloExa.GLOSS: make an agreement that is acceptable to everyone
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: It would usually cost $500, but I'm sure we can come to some kind of arrangement.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: Pets are permitted at the resort

Sense.DEF: the way in which something is organized

EXAMPLE.TEXT: The airport is currently reviewing its

Sense.EXAMPLE: domestic arrangements

Sense.ACTIV: ARRANGE A GROUP OF THINGS OR PEOPLE
Sense.DEF: a group of things that are put in a particular position, or the process of doing this

GramExa.EXAMPLE: the traditional arrangement of desks in rows

Sense.EXAMPLE: a beautiful flower arrangement

Sense.DEF: a piece of music that has been written or changed for a particular instrument
Sense.EXAMPLE: a piano arrangement of an old folk song

Sense.DEF: someone who changes music that has been written by someone else so that it is suitable for a particular instrument or performance
someone who arranges things for other people
used to emphasize how bad something is
a group of people or things, especially one that is large or impressive

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: There was a vast array of colours to choose from.

Sense.DEF: a set of numbers or signs, or of computer memory units, arranged in lines across or down
to wear particular clothes, especially clothes of good quality
Sense.EXAMPLE: She came in arrayed in all her finery.

Sense.DEF: to arrange something in an attractive way

GramExa.EXAMPLE: make-up arrayed on the bathroom counter

if someone is in arrears, or if their payments are in arrears, they are late in paying something that they should pay regularly, such as rent
Sense.EXAMPLE: Many people are in arrears with their rent.

ColloExa.COLLO: be four weeks/three months etc in arrears
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: The rent money is two months in arrears.

ColloExa.GLOSS: become late with payments

Sense.DEF: money that you owe someone because you have not made regular payments at the correct time
Sense.EXAMPLE: We've got 3 months arrears to pay.

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: He was ordered to pay rent arrears of £550.

Sense.DEF: if your salary is paid in arrears, it is paid at the end of the period you have worked
Sense.EXAMPLE: a salary paid monthly in arrears

DEF.TEXT: if the police arrest someone, the person is taken to a
because the police think they have done something illegal

Sense.EXAMPLE: He was arrested and charged with murder.

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Her father was arrested for fraud.

ColloExa.COLLO: arrest sb in connection with sth
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: Five youths were arrested in connection with the attack.

ColloExa.COLLO: arrest sb on charges/suspicion of (doing) sth
ColloExa.EXAMPLE: He was arrested on suspicion of supplying drugs.

Sense.DEF: to stop something happening or to make it happen more slowly
Sense.EXAMPLE: drugs used to arrest the spread of the disease

Sense.DEF: if something arrests you or arrests your attention, you notice it because it is interesting or unusual
Sense.EXAMPLE: The mountains are the most arresting feature of the glen.

Sense.DEF: when the police take someone away and guard them because they may have done something illegal

EXAMPLE.TEXT: following the suspicious death of his wife.

ColloExa.GLOSS: arrest someone

EXAMPLE.GLOSS: when someone who is not guilty is arrested

Sense.DEF: when someone or something arrives somewhere
Sense.EXAMPLE: Only the timely arrival of the police prevented the situation from becoming worse.
Traffic problems account for one third of late arrivals.

GramExa.EXAMPLE: Shortly after our arrival in London, Lisa was attacked.

EXAMPLE.TEXT: A deposit is payable on arrival

Subsense.DEF: the time when a new idea, product etc is first used or discovered
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The demand for phone numbers has increased since the arrival of mobile phones.

Subsense.DEF: the time when an event or period of time starts to happen
Subsense.EXAMPLE: The arrival of winter can make many people feel depressed.

Sense.DEF: someone who has just arrived in a place

EXAMPLE.TEXT: will not be admitted to the theatre.

Sense.DEF: the place at an airport where people arrive when they get off a plane
Sense.EXAMPLE: the arrivals lounge

Sense.DEF: a baby who has just been born
to get to the place you are going to
Sense.EXAMPLE: Give me a call to let me know you've arrived safely.

GramExa.EXAMPLE: What time does the plane arrive in New York?

ColloExa.EXAMPLE: He arrived late as usual.

Sense.DEF: if something arrives, it is brought or delivered to you
Sense.EXAMPLE: The card arrived on my birthday.

Sense.DEF: if an event or particular period of time arrives, it happens
Sense.EXAMPLE: When her wedding day arrived, she was really nervous.

Sense.DEF: if a new idea, method, product etc arrives, it begins to exist or starts being used
Sense.EXAMPLE: Since computers arrived, my job has become much easier.

Sense.DEF: to be born
Sense.EXAMPLE: Sharon's baby arrived just after midnight.

Sense.DEF: to reach a decision, solution etc after a lot of effort
Sense.EXAMPLE: After much consideration, we have arrived at a decision.

Sense.DEF: used to say that someone has become successful or famous
Sense.EXAMPLE: When he saw his name painted on the door he knew he'd arrived!

Sense.DEF: when someone behaves in a rude way because they think they are very important
Sense.EXAMPLE: I couldn't believe the arrogance of the man!

Sense.DEF: behaving in an unpleasant or rude way because you think you are more important than other people
Sense.EXAMPLE: He was unbearably arrogant.
an arrogant attitude

Sense.DEF: to claim that you have a particular right, position etc, without having the legal right to it

Sense.DEF: a sign in the shape of an arrow, used to show direction

Sense.DEF: the sharp pointed end of an arrow
